description: {"blocks":[{"key":"70j17","text":"We conduct a systematic literature review and meta-analysis for the impact of adherence to antidepressants, bisphosphonates or statins on healthcare resource utilisation or healthcare costs, using the articles finding these impacts published between November 2004 and April 2021 searched from PubMed, Cochrane Library, JSTOR, EconLit, and ClinicalTrials.gov.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
document: {"blocks":[{"key":"4roo5","text":"Summary of project","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":18}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"brjna","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cl3gh","text":"Medication adherence (MA) is typically measured as the proportion of days covered (PDC), a single percentage value representing the amount of medication taken relative to that prescribed over a period of time. This project explores the use of the group-based trajectory model (GBTM), which accounts for longitudinal patterns of medication consumption, enabling better understanding of alternative ‘types’ of non-adherence. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"n6is","text":"It explores using GBTM to define MA for Australians using antidepressants, statins and bisphosphonates. It identifies adherence types and their relationship with patient/ healthcare characteristics and healthcare costs. It also evaluates benefits of using GBTM in measuring MA compared to PDC. We utilises New South Wales 45 and Up Study linked with Admitted Patient Data Collection, Emergency Department Data Collection, Cause of Death Unit Record File, Medicare Benefit Schedule data and Pharmaceutical Benefit Schedule data to answer the research questions. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2r44v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"esbva","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fso82","text":"Review question","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ag5ua","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9c3it","text":"Finding the extent to which improving patterns of medication consumption saves valuable healthcare resources is critically important in determining how the research finding of our project will be used in practice. While our research includes the exploration of healthcare cost impacted by MA, we are also conducting this systematic review and meta-analysis to find the answer in broader context. There is lack of literature reviewing the relationship between MA and healthcare resource utilisation and healthcare cost. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a39sh","text":"The aim of this review and meta-analysis is to examine the impact of suboptimal use of antidepressants, statins and bisphosphonates on the pattern of healthcare resource utilisation and healthcare cost shown by use of hospital, visit to healthcare service providers other than hospital, healthcare cost and pharmacy cost.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"t7nq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3k07b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1mmfa","text":"Search journals.name: PLOS One
journals.citation: Park KH, Tickle L, Cutler H (2022) A systematic review and meta-analysis on impact of suboptimal use of antidepressants, bisphosphonates, and statins on healthcare resource utilisation and healthcare cost. PLoS ONE 17(6): e0269836. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0269836

manuscript_citation: Park KH, Tickle L, Cutler H (2022) A systematic review and meta-analysis on impact of suboptimal use of antidepressants, bisphosphonates, and statins on healthcare resource utilisation and healthcare cost. PLoS ONE 17(6): e0269836. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0269836
